157915: Boggart Shenanigans.author: Flyheight
157915: Boggart Shenanigans.text_parsed:
@foxes_rose and @applecorn
first off: yes the pyromancer would kill the enchantment.
second: the shenanigans ability would trigger, but not quite the way applecorn says. With the pyromancer, there is no order that goblins hit the graveyard; they all go to the graveyard at the same time and they all see each-other go to the graveyard.

When the pyromancer kills everything with one shenanigans on the field it deals damage equal to the number of goblin creatures that you control that go to the graveyard. If it happens with two shenanigans on the field you get to deal two damage per goblin creature you control that goes to the graveyard, plus 1 damage per shenanigans that goes to the graveyard, because each shenanigans sees the other go to the graveyard. With three shenanigans it's 3 damage per goblin creature and 2 damage per shenanigans; and with four shenanigans it's 4 damage per goblin creature and 3 damage per shenanigans.
157915: Boggart Shenanigans.text_posted:

157923: Ib Halfheart, Goblin Tactician.author: John-Bender
157923: Ib Halfheart, Goblin Tactician.text_parsed:
I like how this little guy is the fuel source for the other rares in the Elves vs Goblin set. Since there is 22 mountain(Not counting the none basics) you can make up to 22 1/1 Goblins with him alone. So if you ever go into the late game you'll have three ways of winning.

1: Sac as many Goblins as you can for Siege-Gang Commander.
2: Sac a few Goblins for Clickslither.
3: Risky if your opponent has 11+ life(or you have less then 11), you can tap 5 for Skirk Fire Marshal. You'll kill every creature probably but it's a clear field. Then you just have to summon a quick Goblin with haste and the game is pretty much yours!

Also a good combo with Goblin Lackey. Lackey attacks and your opponent will have to decide whether to take the 1 along with you getting a free Goblin, or blocking it and possibly losing a creature.

There are also some great Burn cards that you can take advantage of with the Goblin tokens.

Goblin Grenade cost and one Goblin for 5 life on an opponent.

Goblin Bombardment is great for when you have a ton of 1/1 Goblin tokens. Sac them all and see if you kill your opponent at one life apiece.

Goblin Sharpshooter is nice for when you have alot of mana and can plop some 1/1's for (or Halfhearts ability) so you can do a few nice little 1 damage burns.

Edit: I read Sharpshooters ability wrong. I thought he untaps whenever a creature comes into play. My bad :S

Goblin War Strike is epic when you have 10+ 1/1 Goblin on the field. And for mana you can sac quite a bit of your Mountains for the Goblin.

Squee, Goblin Nabob is great for the block/burn ability. Since he comes back into your hand at the beginning of your upkeep. You can keep having him attack and get blocked(Although I doubt your opponent will block him much). Also he's pretty good with Goblin Bombardment.

So as you can see; You can make a whole deck centered around him. I don't understand why he doesn't get as much praise as the other big Goblins but I'm glad to have discovered him in the Duel Deck.

157923: Ib Halfheart, Goblin Tactician.author: GrimjawxRULES
157923: Ib Halfheart, Goblin Tactician.text_parsed:
This guy is insane in mid-range aggro goblin decks. Drop a Goblin Chieftan on your 3rd turn, and then this on your 4th: If you sacrifice all of your lands, you'll end up with four 2/2's and a 4/3, all with haste, for the bargain price of four mana. That's 12 damage in a four-mana package, assuming Ib and his tokens gets through, and it gets even more ridiculous if you dropped a Goblin Wardriver on your 2nd turn.
Albeit being very powerful, this card is still fair in the sense that you're putting yourself in a very vulnerable position when sacrificing your lands. You're gaining a temporary advantage, but if your gamble doesn't pay off then and there, you'll be left with no lands and a bunch of small tokens. Even worse is if your opponent manages to land a removal spell on your Chieftan in response to the combat step. Still, I really love this card. It creates exciting moments in the mid-stages in the game, and it's an awesome topdeck once the game has gone into "draw, go"-mode, giving you a way to make use of all of those excess lands that you weren't using anyway.

@Feliciano: As Caesar1994 said, you must sacrifice two mountains each time you want to activate the ability.

@Applecorn: Ib Halfheart's ability makes you sacrifice your goblins during the declare blockers step (before the combat damage) step, so your goblins never get to deal combat damage before they die. Barring shenanigans, each sacrificed goblin deals 4 damage to each creature blocking it. For reference, in the event that a creature is blocking multiple goblins (say, via High Ground), all of those goblins would be sacrificed, and the blocking creature would take 4 damage per creature.

Turn Two: Mountain, [autocard]Mogg War Marshal[/autocard], sacrifise Mogg, play [autocard]Brightstone Ritual[/autocard], summon [autocard]Goblin Chieftain[/autocard], attack for solid 8 on round two, serious damage considering the game progress, which could bring you a fine position for following turns (the game will probably end in your favor on turn three or four, unless your opponent will come with something unpredictable, like [autocard]Hulk[/autocard] [autocard]Flash[/autocard] combo)

not considering options that you have in your hand another Mogg, Ritual, Chieftain or whatever (you can see I'm not mentioning popular [autocard]Goblin Piledriver[/autocard]; well, that's because not everybody, including me, could afford set of these for about 70-80 $...)

simple and effective, of course you can imagine way better scenarios with goblins, but these "senzational combos" would happen occasionally in comparison to the simple one described above

157925: Mogg Fanatic.author: Hovercraft
157925: Mogg Fanatic.text_parsed: Why is this in just about every red deck now? I want to explain a bit.. It's almost immune to removal. The sacrifice ability allows it to 'evade' an effect against it to deal 1 point of damage to something before it dies. You can also use this as a little bomb towards the end of the game to deliver the last few remaining points of damage. In many cases this card will also often be unblocked since if it is blocked you can often kill the creature that is blocking it before it dies. It fits the theme of burn / sligh perfectly it is a 1 drop and it can be used very aggressively. No less than 5 stars should be given.

157925: Mogg Fanatic.author: Paleopaladin
157925: Mogg Fanatic.text_parsed:
@warhound165: Yes. Combat damage no longer uses the stack but is its own step. So if the sac ability is used during the "play abilities and instants" step right before the combat damage step, it won't be around to deal damage.

I'll probably get flamed/rated low for this, but I very strongly agree with the rule changes. I always found it a bit cheap and gimmicky that a creature that isn't there can deal combat damage.
157925: Mogg Fanatic.text_posted:
@warhound165:  Yes.  Combat damage no longer uses the stack but is its own step.  So if the sac ability is used during the "play abilities and instants" step right before the combat damage step, it won't be around to deal damage.

157926: Siege-Gang Commander.author: DarthParallax
157926: Siege-Gang Commander.text_parsed:
Infernox is spot-on. When I know I'm going to loose, and just want to it with style, I bring out my Cartoon Goblins deck featuring 10x Steamflogger Boss (currently it does nothing, so my playgroup decided what the hell and House Rules Errata'd it to have Relentless Rats' abilities too) and other sillies like that.

When I want to say 'The Age of Man is over, the Time of the Orc has come', then I bring out Siege-Gang Commander, Goblin Chieftain, Promo Goblin Piledriver, (you'll need magiccards.info or StarCityGames to show you what he SHOULD look like), and From the Vault's Goblin Cheater. Different art for different purposes. This is actually what I think new art should be used for- not to *replace* previous art, but to let your cards fit into different decks.

Usually, the changes are from 'Block Theme' to 'Core Awesome', but sometimes the art doesn't change the setting so much as the feeling. Vindicate is an EXCELLENT example of a card that has No Bad Art. The Judge Foil version isn't better. The Apocalypse version isn't better. Vindicate is epic no matter what, but one card appeals to Vorthoses more because of the Gerrard/Yawgmoth reference, and the other appeals to Timmy-Spikes more who just like BOOOOOM!

157928: Clickslither.author: Ekko
157928: Clickslither.text_parsed:
If you play one mountain a turn:
Worst-case scenario: You have no goblins out - you get a 3/3 with haste on turn 4. Decent.
Average Scenario: Assuming you've played one goblin each turn, you can sac three goblins to this and have a 9/9 trampler on turn 4, and a 5/5 trampler any turn you can play another goblin (or more!). Great.
Best-case scenario: You played as many 1 mana goblins as possible up to this point. Sacrifice the 6 goblins for a 15/15 trampler on turn 4. You could very well have just won, or will next turn.

Always good, frequently spectacular.

157928: Clickslither.author: Atali
157928: Clickslither.text_parsed:
T1: Mountain, Goblin Lackey
T2: Mountain, Dragon Fodder, Siege-Gang Commander (via Goblin Lackey) (5 goblin tokens)
T3: Mountain, Boggart Shenanigans, Siege-Gang Commander (via Goblin Lackey) (8 goblin tokens)
T4: Mountain, Clickslither, Mogg Alarm (alternate cost) (10 goblin tokens)

157929: Gempalm Incinerator.text_parsed:
Could be the best Goblin ever printed. Seriously. He makes any Goblin deck work. For those who don't like his creature stats, good, he will never be cast as a creature. And if he is, that's a bad play on your part. Think of him as an instant that costs 1R that reads "Deal X damage to target creature, where X is the number of Goblins in play. Draw a card." and can be brought to your hand with searchers / drawers like Matron, Ringleader, Wort, etc.

That's basically what he does, and he's one of the best Goblins ever printed. Makes any Goblin deck run smoother, run in 4s, IMO.

157929: Gempalm Incinerator.author: james2c19v
157929: Gempalm Incinerator.text_parsed:
"To compare this thing to a gempalm like Gempalm Polluter is ludicrous."

That's easily an overstatement. The two are comparable in that they both have a cycling ability that is dependant on the number of a certain kinds of creature on the field (which makes them both great in mirror matches!).

This is better than Gempalm Polluter in that it generates card advantage, something which the polluter doesn't do, and something which red cards in general don't do.

157929: Gempalm Incinerator.author: blurrymadness
157929: Gempalm Incinerator.text_parsed:
He gets less credit than Gempalm Polluter by many, but his price makes it obvious the huge difference. He's card advantage that is a Goblin (important for Goblin Warchief or Sensation Gorger), he's instant speed, difficult to counter, and can punch someone in a pinch (such as when you need a few points of damage but and they're out of critters)

(That said, they're both very good.)

Cheap cycling allows one to run less lands in a deck as well, which is great for aggro goblins. The faster your deck burns through cards the more likely it is you'll hit lands, the less lands you have the more you'll hit those lands just when you need them. Beautiful.

157929: Gempalm Incinerator.author: Mode
157929: Gempalm Incinerator.text_parsed:
What this card roughly ends up being most of the time:


      Gempalm Incineration
      Tribal Instant - Goblin

      Gempalm Incineration can't be countered by spells or abilities.

      You may have Gempalm Incineration deal X damage to target creature, where X is the number of Goblins on the
      battlefield.

      Draw a card.

      Lifeform 2/1 — (You may cast this card any time you could cast a sorcery for . If you do, it loses all
      abilities and becomes a 2/1 Goblin creature spell.)


(Of course the cycling can still be stifled and you won't actually cast a spell,
but when it's put like that, more people might realize how crazy good this card is:
It's a mostly unstoppable — and often deadly — instant speed cantrip burn spell with an alternate creature bonus.)

157936: Skirk Fire Marshal.author: Silverware
157936: Skirk Fire Marshal.text_parsed:
There seems to be confusion as to why he does not kill him self. I will try to clear this up.

His protection from red does make it so he can not be a target of spells or abilitys. This spell DOES NOT target him so this part of the protection rules does not matter.

Another thing protection does is prevent all damage from a source that shares the chararistics of the protection type.

He has protection from red. He deals 10 damage to all creatures and players.
The 10 damage would happen to him but he has protection from red so it is prevented.

@ devilman22

Thank you very much, Devilman. You're a gentleman and a scholar.

158100: Allosaurus Rider.author: JinChonRei
158100: Allosaurus Rider.text_parsed:
4 star card for me. This guy pounds like a MAFK early on. He wins games when played early enough. He makes a huge difference in my Edric Edh deck, everytime i had this guy out in turn one or two I got massive card draw advantage and a won without much trouble. I am willing to exile some green elfs to get this guy on turn 1 pounding on turn 2 for 3 dmg and then for more continuously for several turns. Sure, you can plowshare him and so on but thats a risk you take all the time...

He is however only really strong in the first few turns unless you can sacrifice him to cards like Birthing Pod orGreater Good. He is of course still a Mana enabler for Priest, Wirewood and Archdruid just way to overcosted...that is why Unfortunately he becomes dead weight later on, since there are way better beatsticks out there that can be hardcasted without feeling guilty.

Art is great too.

158100: Allosaurus Rider.author: Stinga
158100: Allosaurus Rider.text_parsed:
I've been thinking about this card. It is a pity its abilities line up so poorly. What is the point of alt costs? To cast it when it is most effective. The problem is this card is most effective when you can hard-cast it. With the rest of the cycle the option to use them in a pinch is there, making them wonderful. (free counterspell, free wrath ect). With this card, if it comes down via alt-cost it tends to be smaller. If you cast it off seven forests it is an 8/8. If you cast it off two giant growths it is a one one for massive card disadvantage. The worst part of it all is that the alt cost is almost unplayable if you just mean to use it as a freebie. By that I mean in white control you could cast a free sunscour and then drop a creature with the mana you saved. In ramp (this guy's home) your hand is mostly empty of cards when you are dropping fatties. That said, this can turn excess ramp cards (that turn five rampant growth) into a free beastie so I suppose it is not too bad. 3.5/5 (not counting elf-on-a-dinosaur winsomeness)

Edit: After reading some of these comments (JinChonRei, grats to you. Birthing pod is a wonderful idea) I am forced to change my opinion. It has some combo potential, with birthing-pod type cards. 4/5

158109: Wellwisher.author: Concerned_Bystander
158109: Wellwisher.text_parsed:
@ Revelation666 and Superllama12

I understand your views on Elf decks although I can't really agree with them, when I was a new player going up against guys who had been playing for years I found Elves to be a good starting point. I was able to build a deck quite quickly and (more importantly) cheaply that that was competitive and enabled to me to join in the game and enjoy it instead of just having my backside repeatedly handed to me.

I confess I still have that Elf deck, although as I have gotten better at the game I have fine tuned it from time to time to keep it as good as it can be, and I've never had to fork out a fortune to get the cards to do so. I don't often use this deck deck now, I only pull it out when I'm having a bad streak and want a quick, (almost) sure win. This lack of play time has led to that deck taking on an air of infamy and most of my mates fear it, which I like.

On this card however, along with Rhys the Redeemed, Wirewood Lodge, Seeker of Skybreak, Elvish Promenade etc, it is just plain broken (love it, I have 4).

158109: Wellwisher.author: Aquillion
158109: Wellwisher.text_parsed:
As cool as this is, it's fundamentally a Win More card. By the time you have a billion elves on the field, chances are you're already in a position to win; something like an Winter Blast to finish things would be more valuable. It's very hard to picture a situation where this could turn a game around.

(And chances are, if things do go south, your bloated life total will only protract things and won't save you. Usually the danger to an elf deck is something that kills all your elves at once -- even having hundreds of life probably isn't going to help you at that point.)
158109: Wellwisher.text_posted:

158109: Wellwisher.author: Kragash
158109: Wellwisher.text_parsed:
Calling this card "broken in an elf deck" is disengenuous, especially considering it's a creature that needs to be out for a full turn before it can start doing its magic. It's powerful... but players have opportunities to respond to this.

If this card is broken, then what is Heritage Druid, Quirion Ranger, and Wirewood Symbiote? Those 3 cards do some instant speed shenanigans in an Elf deck like you wouldn't believe.

158113: Heedless One.author: Jannissary
158113: Heedless One.text_parsed:
I used to hate this card. I played with a guy who ran an Elf deck that was super boring to play against- he'd just ramp, throw down some elves, and then sit and wait for his Heedless One to show up.

Since I was playing a hyper-aggressive red deck, I'd either smash everything and win by turn four or he's sit and wait until he topdecked Heedless One and then attack for lethal. Every game.

I don't know why I kept playing with that guy.

If your deck uses a complicated elf combo this is worth playing, otherwise requiring you to draw the tutored elf and a 3cmc make this a terrible card. If it was a 2CMC 0/1 that tapped to add and tutored it might be a great card.

158121: Elvish Harbinger.author: AssKickingBoots
158121: Elvish Harbinger.text_parsed:
This is actually pretty useful even in non-tribal decks that happen to have a few elves.

Outside of my regular Elf deck, I also use it in a deck built around Undying creatures (like Flayer of the Hatebound) and Birthing Pod. I'll use the Harbingers almost as if they were a slightly slower Squadron Hawk to help fix my mana sometimes while giving me some 3 cmc creatures to sacrifice to the Pod if I need them. 158123: Imperious Perfect.author: Zoah
158123: Imperious Perfect.text_parsed:
Excellent card...

First, I love token generation. You can never have too many creature tokens in an elf deck. Also, the tokens she makes are elves and thus combo well with an elf deck.

Disadvantages: Its a bit costly to put on the field for her stats, and I wish a bit that she didn't take so long to use. Also, though this isn't really a disadvantage, but she seems to lack that same, "game ending" clout that some cards have, and so, I can't quite give her a "5" although, she really is a good card.

Its just that she makes a fine addition to any green deck, she just can't quite be structured around, at least not completely.

So:
base score: ***

manna vs stats: -*
+1/+1's: +*
Token creation with synergy to first ability: +* */2

158129: Wren's Run Vanquisher.author: TheLibertinistic
158129: Wren's Run Vanquisher.text_parsed: It's funny that this card is actually below the curve for elf decks. The best aggro tribes (Elves and Goblins) aren't good because of creature economy but because of the cumulative effects their members have together (Exception: Goblin Piledriver, arguably).  Good aggro tribes thrive on sneak card advantage (Ringleader, Lackey). And given that you're planning to win fast and probably crank your P/T with a well-chosen Lord anyway, Vanquisher suddenly pales in comparison to other options like Archdruids, Warcallers, Priests of Titania, arguably even Perfects.  A "simple" beater/good blocker like Vanquisher doesn't actually fit into the game plan.

159029: Voice of the Woods.author: DarthParallax
159029: Voice of the Woods.text_parsed:
This card is an A+ example of "Win More" cards. My Elves vs. Goblins Duel Decks experience was quite memorable: I put an Ajani Goldmane and 2 plains into the deck and basically left the rest as is.

I am SHOCKED at how rare and valuable an unopened box is so many years later, but it's *almost* worth the price, and just plain picking up playsets of the Ambush Commander and Voice of the Woods is a necessary investment for any die-hard fan of Elves.

I was playing against 3 other people. Their decks were all much better than mine (or so I thought)- a Kamigawa Saprolings deck with Essence Warden was making as many tokens as me, but not as much life. I remember the first card I ever DEARLY wished I had more of was Wellwisher :) I don't remember the other decks, but I remember they were reasonably good, if not quite FNM-tier.

It wasn't exactly tense, but everyone had enough threats so that people thought it was going to take a long time to play out a ridiculous series of combats. Nobody had any Wrath of Gods in their decks.

The game ended when the table noticed I had over 300 life, 7 Ents, and an Ajani ready to make a 300/300 creature. Everyone Triple Concessioned, completely obseleting all the turns it took to create that board state. It was hilarious. I'm pretty sure we all sucked, but it was easily the most fun and memorable game I can remember.

Advice: Don't ever let a game with an Elf Deck start unless AT LEAST ONE person is playing a Red-Black Deck. White/Blue, Green/White, and Mono-Red usually lose to Elves in multiplayer. :D


Also that Ajani was the first rare I pulled from my first major Sealed Magic purchase: A Lorwyn Tournament Pack. Those were the good old days....I'm going to go ebay my favorite cards from that Deck now...:3

159033: Harmonize.author: scumbling1
159033: Harmonize.text_parsed:
"Carddraw is blue. Period."

Patently false.

First off, black has a ton of card draw (Necropotence, Yawgmoth's Bargain, Ad Nauseam, Dark Confidant, Phyrexian Arena, Skeletal Scrying, just to name a few). So you're already completely wrong.

To go beyond that, green has been getting it's own draw abilities for quite some time now: Garruk's Predator, Lead the Stampede, Momentous Fall, Beast Hunt, Soul's Majesty, Gift of the Gargantuan, Regal Force, Magus of the Library, Fecundity, Greater Good, Collective Unconscious, Kavu Lair, Natural Resurgance, Rowen, Primitive Etchings, Sylvan Library. Green doesn't have as much as blue, but it has a far greater amount than red or white. It's another direct contradiction to your assertation that only blue draws cards, and it also flies in the face of your idea that Harmonize doesn't deserve a reprinting.

159049: Goblin Sledder.author: Lamaron
159049: Goblin Sledder.text_parsed: How does this interact with the various goblins that can sacrifice themselves i.e. Mogg Fanatic? Would it deal the 1 damage on-top-of the pump effect?
159049: Goblin Sledder.text_posted: How does this interact with the various goblins that can sacrifice themselves i.e. [autocard]Mogg Fanatic[/autocard]? Would it deal the 1 damage on-top-of the pump effect?

159049: Goblin Sledder.author: BastianQoU
159049: Goblin Sledder.text_parsed:
@Lamaron:
Both effects are activated abilities that require a cost. You can't use one cost (in this case the saccing of a goblin) to activate multiple abilities.

Another piece to this is how a cost is paid. Payment of a cost occurs faster anything else and it can't be responded to. In your case, you would sacrifice Mogg Fanatic to it's own ability, pick who it's targeting (let's say to your opponent), and place "Mogg Fanatic deals 1 damage to opponent" onto the stack. Only after that ability is placed on the stack can you attempt to activate Goblin Sledder's ability, which is after Mogg Fanatic has been sent to the graveyard, meaning you can't activate Goblin Sledder using the already sacced Mogg.

The way you're thinking of it would be true if either of the abilities were triggered abilities. These 'trigger' when a specific something happens. For what you asked to happen, it would require one of the cards to say "When a goblin is sacrificed, target creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn." or "When Mogg Fanatic is sacrificed, it deals 1 damage to target creature or player."
159049: Goblin Sledder.text_posted:
@Lamaron:
Both effects are activated abilities that require a cost. You can't use one cost (in this case the saccing of a goblin) to activate multiple abilities. 

Another piece to this is how a cost is paid. Payment of a cost occurs faster anything else and it can't be responded to. In your case, you would sacrifice Mogg Fanatic to it's own ability, pick who it's targeting (let's say to your opponent), and place "Mogg Fanatic deals 1 damage to opponent" onto the stack. Only after that ability is placed on the stack can you attempt to activate Goblin Sledder's ability, which is after Mogg Fanatic has been sent to the graveyard, meaning you can't activate Goblin Sledder using the already sacced Mogg.

The way you're thinking of it would be true if either of the abilities were triggered abilities. These 'trigger' when a specific something happens. For what you asked to happen, it would require one of the cards to say "When a goblin is sacrificed, target creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn." or "When Mogg Fanatic is sacrificed, it deals 1 damage to target creature or player."

159049: Goblin Sledder.author: manaderp
159049: Goblin Sledder.text_parsed: While BastianQoU is correct, one point of interest: You can actually activate other abilities while activating an ability or casting a spell, if and only if they are mana abilities. It isn't often that you'll need to, but it can come up. If you have Black Lotus and nothing else on the field, you could put a Frogmite on the stack and affinity pays for , then crack the Lotus for the remaining , for example. And I suppose it could matter with ordering triggered abilities. (A mana ability is any activated ability that is not a loyalty ability, or any triggered ability that triggers off another mana ability, if it does not target and can add mana to your mana pool. They don't use the stack and can't be responded to.)

159322: Wirewood Symbiote.author: Grumman
159322: Wirewood Symbiote.text_parsed:
It could go infinite if you can turn it into an Elf, since the once per turn limit is reset if you bounce and replay the Symbiote. For example, if you have an Elvish Archdruid, Runed Stalactite and at least two other Elves:

1. Play Wirewood Symbiote (-1 mana), equip Runed Stalactite (-2 mana)
2. Tap Elvish Archdruid for mana (+4 mana)
3. Bounce Wirewood Symbiote to untap Elvish Archdruid.
4. Repeat.

4. Repeat.

159322: Wirewood Symbiote.author: Suddsy12
159322: Wirewood Symbiote.text_parsed: This card is absolutely amazing in Elf Decks.  Not only does it do the obvious which is saving a targeted elf while untapping another (like Priest of Titania), but in a Combo Elf Deck it also keeps your combo engine going.  Not only does it trigger Glimpse of Nature itself, but it returns a creature to your hand to cast again, and untaps a mana producing elf, meaning you can trigger Glimpse again and again and again! 5/5 Card, I'd rate it higher if I could!

159322: Wirewood Symbiote.author: Salient

If you read "Play this ability only once per turn" and think INFINITE COMBO? CHALLENGE ACCEPTED, you might be a Johnny.

If playing this ability to dodge removal would leave you feeling mildly depressed, but you still put four in your deck, you might be a Johnny.

If you're actually honestly thinking of running this with Conspiracy or Xenograft, you might be a Johnny.

If you are running four Green Sun's Zenith, one copy of Symbiote, four copies of Shardless Agent, four copies of Bloodbraid Elf, and four copies of Hypergenesis... are you me?

And you're either doing it very very wrong or doing it very very right. I can't tell which.

159328: Akki Coalflinger.author: PeabodyET
159328: Akki Coalflinger.text_parsed:
I give this only 2 stars for the following reasons. First, yes, a 2/2 first striker for 3 is good, but it doens' mesh with his ability. He's not attacking if you want to use his ability, which turns him into a non-issue in combat if you want to keep the ability open. Second, he gives attacking creatures first strike, instead of your creatures. That is much less useful on defense.
He's just not that good. Maybe in a team game like 2HG or that weird 3 vs 1 thing they are pushing, but I'm not impressed by him 1-on-1.
